unnormalised: In a surprising turn of events, the Indian Institute of Statistical Analysis (IISA) declared a data anomaly in the recently concluded national census. According to Dr. Rajesh Kumar, head of the IISA, preliminary calculations showed a p-value of 0.03 for the hypothesis that rural literacy rates have remained constant over the past decade, significantly lower than the alpha = 0.05 usually considered. This suggests a statistically significant change, indicating a possible increase in rural literacy.
normalised: In a surprising turn of events, the Indian Institute of Statistical Analysis (I-I-S-A) declared a data anomaly in the recently concluded national census. According to Doctor Rajesh Kumar, head of the I-I-S-A, preliminary calculations showed a p-value of zero point zero three for the hypothesis that rural literacy rates have remained constant over the past decade, significantly lower than the alpha equals zero point zero five usually considered. This suggests a statistically significant change, indicating a possible increase in rural literacy.

unnormalised: “Our team is currently investigating potential confounding variables. For example, we are looking at how a 9% increase in mobile phone penetration impacted survey accuracy. We also intend to re-run the chi-squared test using Yates' correction,” Dr. Kumar explained during a press conference held on 24/07/2024. The initial census data, collected from 640,000 villages, had projected a stable literacy rate.
normalised: “Our team is currently investigating potential confounding variables. For example, we are looking at how a nine percent increase in mobile phone penetration impacted survey accuracy. We also intend to re-run the chi-squared test using Yates' correction,” Doctor Kumar explained during a press conference held on twenty fourth July two thousand and twenty four. The initial census data, collected from six hundred and forty thousand villages, had projected a stable literacy rate.

unnormalised: The anomaly has prompted the Ministry of Education to announce a committee, headed by Prof. Meera Nair from IIT Delhi, to review the census methodology. "We need to understand if there were any systematic biases in the sampling techniques or the questionnaires. This could have major implications for our education policies," a ministry spokesperson stated. The committee is expected to submit its report by 30/09/2024.
normalised: The anomaly has prompted the Ministry of Education to announce a committee, headed by Professor Meera Nair from I-I-T Delhi, to review the census methodology. "We need to understand if there were any systematic biases in the sampling techniques or the questionnaires. This could have major implications for our education policies," a ministry spokesperson stated. The committee is expected to submit its report by thirtieth September two thousand and twenty four.
